questionContent.body: What ICMP message type is sent when a router cannot forward a packet due to TTL expiry

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The “Time Exceeded” message (Type 11) is sent when a packet’s TTL reaches zero.

questionContent.body: Which ICMP message type is used by the ping command

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Ping uses ICMP Echo Request (Type 8) and Echo Reply (Type 0) messages.

questionContent.body: You added a static route, but it's not used even though the destination matches. What could be the cause

questionOptions.body: Lower administrative distance of another route

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A dynamic protocol with a lower AD will override a static route.

questionContent.body: Your device fails to reach 192.168.1.100. You verify IP and MAC are correct. Ping works, but file sharing doesn’t. What layer is at fault

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Application-layer protocols handle services like file sharing.

questionContent.body: An OSPF router in Area 0 is not receiving routes from Area 1. What's likely wrong

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: All areas must connect properly to the backbone (Area 0) for inter-area routing.

questionContent.body: You notice that OSPF is using a slower link even though a faster one exists. What should you check

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: OSPF uses interface cost; lower cost routes are preferred.

questionContent.body: Two routers are sending each other incorrect routes, forming a loop. What should be implemented

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: These are loop prevention mechanisms used in distance vector protocols.

questionContent.body: You enable RIPv2, but the router isn't sending updates. What could be the cause

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A passive interface prevents RIP from sending updates on that interface.

questionContent.body: An ARP entry is missing for a valid IP address. What could be the cause

questionOptions.body: IP address is on a different subnet

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ARP only resolves MAC addresses within the same subnet.

questionContent.body: You add a new route in OSPF, but traffic still goes through a static route. Why

questionOptions.body: Static route has a higher metric

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Static routes override OSPF because of a lower administrative distance.

questionContent.body: Two routers connected via Ethernet aren’t forming OSPF adjacency. OSPF is configured. What should you check

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Mismatched Hello/Dead intervals prevent OSPF neighbors from forming adjacencies.

questionContent.body: You ping a device and get “Destination host unreachable.” What layer is likely at fault

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The error suggests a routing or IP address issue at the network layer.

questionContent.body: In a network with multiple routers running RIP, a link fails. Routers take 2 minutes to update. What’s the likely issue

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIP is a slow-converging protocol due to periodic updates.

questionContent.body: You’ve configured two static routes to the same destination. One has an administrative distance of 1, the other 5. Which one is used

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Lower administrative distance is always preferred.

questionContent.body: Which of these IP protocols does not perform routing

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ICMP is not a routing protocol but used for diagnostics and control.

questionContent.body: What does the administrative distance (AD) indicate

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: AD is used to rank route sources by trust; lower is more preferred.

questionContent.body: What differentiates classful and classless routing

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Classless routing protocols carry subnet mask information with updates.

questionContent.body: Which router role exists only in OSPF multi-access networks

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The DR is unique to OSPF in multi-access environments like Ethernet.

questionContent.body: What is the primary limitation of RIP in large networks

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIP suffers from slow convergence and a maximum hop count of 15.

questionContent.body: Which condition triggers an OSPF LSA update

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: LSAs are generated when a topology change is detected.

questionContent.body: Which protocol works directly over Layer 2 without needing IP

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ARP operates at the data link layer to resolve MAC addresses.

questionContent.body: What does an OSPF DR (Designated Router) do

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The DR reduces OSPF traffic by centralizing LSA exchange in multi-access networks.

questionContent.body: Which of the following uses cost as its routing metric

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: OSPF uses cost, based on bandwidth, as its routing metric.

questionContent.body: What is the main advantage of link-state routing protocols

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Link-state protocols converge faster and provide a more accurate view of the network.

questionContent.body: Which field in an IP header helps prevent infinite looping of packets

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: TTL is decremented at each hop, and the packet is dropped when it reaches 0.

questionContent.body: Why is OSPF considered more scalable than RIPv2

questionOptions.body: It supports areas and hierarchical design

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: OSPF divides networks into areas for scalability.

questionContent.body: Which of these routing protocols supports variable length subnet masks (VLSM)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 supports classless routing and VLSM.

questionContent.body: What happens during OSPF’s Dijkstra SPF algorithm execution

questionOptions.body: Finds shortest path from all routers to a destination
Finds shortest path from a router to all destinations

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The SPF algorithm finds the shortest path from one router to all networks.

questionContent.body: Which of the following prevents routing loops in distance vector protocols

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Split horizon and poison reverse help avoid routing loops in distance vector routing.

questionContent.body: In OSPF, what is a "Hello" packet used for

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Hello packets are used to discover and maintain neighbor relationships.

questionContent.body: How does RIPv2 reduce routing update traffic compared to RIP v1

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 uses multicast instead of broadcast, reducing unnecessary traffic.

questionContent.body: Which of the following best describes the difference between distance vector and link-state routing protocols

questionOptions.body: Distance vector shares entire topology; link-state shares next hop
Distance vector sends full table periodically; link-state sends triggered updates
Link-state builds entire network map; distance vector doesn't

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Link-state protocols like OSPF build a complete network topology, unlike distance vector.

questionContent.body: Which of these is a classless routing protocol

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 supports CIDR, making it classless, unlike RIPv1.

questionContent.body: Which protocol is used to discover the MAC address of the next hop

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ARP resolves MAC addresses on local networks for next-hop delivery.

questionContent.body: Which protocol uses type and code fields in its header

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ICMP messages are classified using type and code fields.

questionContent.body: What is the default administrative distance of RIPv2

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 has a default AD of 120, lower preference than OSPF or static.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT a feature of dynamic routing

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Manual configuration is a static routing characteristic, not dynamic.

questionContent.body: Which protocol broadcasts routing updates every 30 seconds

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 periodically sends updates every 30 seconds to maintain routing info.

questionContent.body: In routing, what is convergence

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Convergence is when routers agree on consistent routing tables.

questionContent.body: Which protocol uses Dijkstra's algorithm

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: OSPF uses Dijkstra’s Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm.

questionContent.body: Which version of RIP supports classless routing

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 supports subnet masks and CIDR, enabling classless routing.

questionContent.body: What kind of protocol is OSPF

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: OSPF is a link-state protocol that builds a map of the network topology.

questionContent.body: Which protocol sends error messages and operational information

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ICMP is used to send error messages like "destination unreachable."

questionContent.body: What type of routing is manually configured

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Static routing requires manual configuration and doesn't change automatically.

questionContent.body: Which layer does the IP protocol belong to

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IP operates at the Network Layer in the OSI model.

questionContent.body: What is the function of a routing protocol

questionOptions.body: Determine best path for packet delivery

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Routing protocols determine the most efficient path to send data.

questionContent.body: What is the maximum hop count for RIPv2

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 considers any route beyond 15 hops as unreachable.

questionContent.body: Which protocol uses hop count as a metric

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: RIPv2 selects routes based on the number of hops, preferring fewer hops.

questionContent.body: What is the administrative distance of static routes

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Static routes have an administrative distance of 1, indicating high trust.

questionContent.body: What does ICMP stand for

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ICMP is used for diagnostics and error reporting in network devices.

questionContent.body: Which protocol is used for mapping IP addresses to MAC addresses

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ARP translates IP addresses to physical MAC addresses on local networks.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a dynamic routing protocol

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: OSPF is a dynamic protocol that automatically updates routing tables.

questionContent.body: Why does IPv6 not have a header checksum

questionOptions.body: Efficiency and reliance on link-layer or transport-layer checks

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Omitting checksum improves processing speed and relies on lower layers.

questionContent.body: Which field in IPv6 replaces the IPv4 Protocol field

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Next Header field specifies the upper-layer protocol (like TCP).

questionContent.body: What does the Flow Label field in the IPv6 header specify

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Flow Label helps identify traffic flows requiring special handling.

questionContent.body: Which field in the IPv6 header is used to prioritize traffic

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Traffic Class is used for packet classification and prioritization.

questionContent.body: What is the maximum size of the IPv4 header

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IPv4 headers can be 20 to 60 bytes long if options are included.

questionContent.body: Which field in the IPv4 header ensures data integrity of the header

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The Header Checksum verifies the integrity of the IPv4 header only.

questionContent.body: What is the purpose of the Identification field in the IPv4 header

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The field helps in identifying and reassembling fragmented packets.

questionContent.body: Which field in the IPv4 header indicates the protocol used in the data portion of the packet

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The Protocol field specifies the next-layer protocol (e.g., TCP, UDP).

questionContent.body: In IPv6, your network needs automatic IP configuration without DHCP. What technique is used

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration) allows devices to self-configure.

questionContent.body: A router receives a packet for 10.0.1.5. It has two routes: 10.0.0.0/8 and 10.0.1.0/24. Which route will it take

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Longest prefix match is used in routing. /24 is more specific than /8.

questionContent.body: You need to assign 20 IP addresses for a department. Which subnet mask will you choose

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A /27 subnet provides 32 IPs, 30 usable for hosts, sufficient for 20 devices.

questionContent.body: Given two subnets: 192.168.10.0/25 and 192.168.10.128/25, what is the supernet

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Supernetting merges adjacent subnets. These two /25 networks combine into a /24 supernet.

questionContent.body: Your organization needs 500 hosts. What is the smallest subnet mask you can use

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /23 gives 512 total addresses, 510 usable for hosts.

questionContent.body: An ISP wants to allocate IP ranges to customers in /28 blocks. How many such blocks can be created from 10.0.0.0/24

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 2^(28–24) = 16 IPs per block, 256/16 = 16 blocks.

questionContent.body: A company has been allocated 172.16.0.0/16. They need 100 subnets. Which subnet mask is suitable

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /22 provides 1024 subnets in a /16 block (2^6 = 64 subnets).

questionContent.body: You have the network 192.168.1.0/24. You need 4 subnets. What subnet mask will you use

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /27 gives 8 subnets with 32 IPs each, enough for 4 subnets.

questionContent.body: Which class has the smallest number of usable hosts

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Class C provides only 254 usable host addresses.

questionContent.body: What is the purpose of subnetting

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Subnetting enables more efficient IP usage and segmentation.

questionContent.body: Which technique reduces routing table size

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Supernetting aggregates multiple entries, reducing table size.

questionContent.body: What is the range of valid host addresses for 192.168.10.0/28

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The first address is network and the last is broadcast, leaving 1–14 as valid hosts.

questionContent.body: IPv6 uses which type of address resolution

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: SLAAC enables stateless auto-configuration in IPv6.

questionContent.body: What is the broadcast address for 10.10.0.0/18

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /18 gives 16384 addresses; last address is 10.10.63.255.

questionContent.body: A supernet can be created when

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Supernetting aggregates adjacent networks with the same prefix.

questionContent.body: In IPv6, how many possible addresses exist

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long.

questionContent.body: What is the network address for IP 172.16.45.14/20

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The block size is 16, so the nearest lower multiple is 32.

questionContent.body: How many subnets are possible in a /24 network when subnetted to /28

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 2⁴ = 16 subnets when moving from /24 to /28.

questionContent.body: How many usable hosts are there in a /26 subnet

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 2⁶ = 64 addresses, minus 2 for network and broadcast gives 62 usable.

questionContent.body: What is the subnet mask of a /20 network

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /20 corresponds to 255.255.240.0, allowing 4096 IPs (minus 2 for network and broadcast).

questionContent.body: The network portion of 10.0.0.0/8 is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /8 means that the first 8 bits represent the network portion.

questionContent.body: IPv4 address exhaustion led to the introduction of

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IPv6 was introduced to provide a vastly larger address space.

questionContent.body: Which notation is used to denote subnetting in CIDR

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) uses a forward slash to denote prefix length.

questionContent.body: The binary equivalent of 192 is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 192 in decimal is 11000000 in binary.

questionContent.body: Which IP class supports 16 million hosts

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Class A supports approximately 16 million hosts with its 24 host bits.

questionContent.body: Supernetting is also referred to as

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Supernetting merges multiple smaller networks into a larger block.

questionContent.body: Which protocol helps in assigning IP addresses dynamically

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) assigns IP addresses automatically.

questionContent.body: In IPv6, the abbreviation  means

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The double colon (::) compresses contiguous blocks of zeros.

questionContent.body: The smallest subnet mask that allows 30 hosts is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: /27 provides 32 addresses, of which 30 are usable (2 are reserved for network and broadcast).

questionContent.body: Which of these is a private IP address
Which IP address is reserved for APIPA

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Automatic IP assigned by OS when DHCP fails.

questionContent.body: The broadcast address of 192.168.1.0/24 is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Last address in subnet is the broadcast.

questionContent.body: What is the default subnet mask for a Class B address

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Class B uses the first two octets for network.

questionContent.body: What does CIDR stand for

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: CIDR allows for flexible subnetting.

questionContent.body: Which class of IP address is used for multicast

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Class D (224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255) is reserved for multicast.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a valid IPv6 address

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Valid IPv6 contains 8 blocks of hex numbers.

questionContent.body: IPv6 address consists of how many bits

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IPv6 provides a larger address space.

questionContent.body: What is the loopback IP address in IPv4

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Loopback is used for internal testing.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a valid IPv4 address

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IPv4 octets range from 0–255.

questionContent.body: What is the size of an IPv4 address

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: IPv4 uses 32+H2:H93-bit addressing.
